Expenditures related to the acquisition of spectrum licences and additions to right-of-use assets are not included in capital expenditures and do not factor into the calculation of free cash flow or capital intensity. See “Managing Our Liquidity and Financial Resources”, “Key Performance Indicators”, and “Non-GAAP Measures and Related Performance Measures” for more information.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response: The basic EPS is the total of the basic and diluted earnings per share for the period. The diluted EPS is calculated by dividing the basic EPS by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period. Diluted earnings per share is determined based on the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.

Basic earnings per share, or EPS, is calculated by dividing net income (loss) per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.

• A $17 million increase in capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to an increase in our LTE-A network build-out, a faster roll-out of LTE-A services to customers and an improvement in our small-cell deployments
• A $10 million increase in capital investments in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to an increase in our investments in our fixed WTTP network, improvements in our network performance and a reduction in our investments in fixed WTTP due to lower capital investment in fixed WTTP
• A $7 million increase in capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to an increase in our investments in our LTE-A network build-out, a faster roll-out of LTE-A services to customers and an improvement in our small-cell deployments

• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
